name: abroad
content:
abroad adverb [after verb]
(OTHER COUNTRY)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B1 in or to a foreign country or countries: go abroad We always go abroad in the summer. He's currently abroad on business.
More examplesFewer examplesAfter her divorce she went to live abroad.He wanted the best for his children - good schools, a nice house and trips abroad.We have two grown-up children, both of whom live abroad.They decided to move abroad and make a fresh start.Some very well-known British football players have gone to clubs abroad.

Grammar
AbroadAbroad means ‘in/to a foreign country’. We use abroad as an adverb in phrases such as go abroad and live abroad. From is the only preposition that is used before abroad: …

in or to a foreign country or countries: They used to go abroad every summer.
